sections.title: Syntax
sections.raw_content:
(a) int1     % 1-byte integer
  (b) int2     % 2-byte integer
  (c) int4     % 4-byte integer

sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The intn (n-byte integer) types are machine-dependent types that occupy a specified number of bytes. By contrast, the int type is in principle a machine-independent and mathematical type (it overflows, however, when the value is too large or small, that is, when the value does not fit into 4 bytes).
sections.text_content: The intn (n-byte integer) types are machine-dependent types that occupy a specified number of bytes. By contrast, the int type is in principle a machine-independent and mathematical type (it overflows, however, when the value is too large or small, that is, when the value does not fit into 4 bytes).
sections.mdown_content: The **int_n_** (_n_-byte integer) types are machine-dependent types that occupy a specified number of bytes. By contrast, the **int** type is in principle a machine-independent and mathematical type (it overflows, however, when the value is too large or small, that is, when the value does not fit into 4 bytes).

sections.title: Example
code:
var counter1 : int1 % Range is -128 .. 127
        var counter2 : int2 % Range is -32768 .. 32767
        var counter4 : int4 % Range is -2147483648 .. 2147483647

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
In current implementations of Turing, the range of the int is -2147483647 to 2147483647, which means that the int4 type allows one more value, -2147483648. This extra value is used in int to represent the state of being initialized. The intn types allow use of all possible values that fit into n bytes and thereby cannot check for initialization.

The intn types are like the C language types short int, int, and long int, except that the number of bytes occupied by the C types depends on the particular C compiler.
sections.text_content:
In current implementations of Turing, the range of the int is -2147483647 to 2147483647, which means that the int4 type allows one more value, -2147483648. This extra value is used in int to represent the state of being initialized. The intn types allow use of all possible values that fit into n bytes and thereby cannot check for initialization.
The intn types are like the C language types short int, int, and long int, except that the number of bytes occupied by the C types depends on the particular C compiler.
sections.mdown_content:
In current implementations of Turing, the range of the **int** is -2147483647 to 2147483647, which means that the **int4** type allows one more value, -2147483648. This extra value is used in **int** to represent the state of being initialized. The **int_n_** types allow use of all possible values that fit into _n_ bytes and thereby cannot check for initialization.

The **int_n_** types are like the C language types _short int_, _int_, and _long int_, except that the number of bytes occupied by the C types depends on the particular C compiler.

sections.title: See also
sections.raw_content: the natn types which are n byte natural (non-negative) values. See also int and nat.
sections.text_content: the natn types which are n byte natural (non-negative) values. See also int and nat.
sections.mdown_content: the **[nat.html](nat)**_n_ types which are _n_ byte natural (non-negative) values. See also **[int.html](int)** and **[nat.html](nat)**.
